text:
American Airlines name pilot who died during flight MARY SCHLANGENSTEIN Last updated 09:51, October 7 2015 
Audio recording of the moment first officer radios ground control to say captain was 'incapacitated' 
American Airlines have named Michael Johnston as the pilot who died midway through a Phoenix- to-Boston flight. 
His wife, Betty Jean Johnston, told NBC News that her husband likely suffered a heart attack. Johnston, 57, joined America West Airlines in January 1990, Chief Executive Officer Doug Parker told American employees in a message. Supplied 
American Airlines pilot Michael Johnston is though to have died from a heart-related incident. America West later acquired US Airways Group, which merged with American in 2013.Johnston, a captain, was based in Phoenix. American declined further comment. The first officer of Flight 550 was forced to take over the Airbus Group SE A320 when Johnston became disabled, and diverted the flight to an emergency landing at Syracuse, New York. The flight left Phoenix carrying 147 passengers and five crew members. The passengers arrived in Boston after American dispatched a new crew to Syracuse, said Ross Feinstein, an American spokesman. READ MORE: American Airlines captain dead after falling ill during flight A pilot's death in flight is a rare occurrence, but not unprecedented. Cockpit automation has helped ensure safety in case of the loss of one of the two crew members on the flight deck, ensuring that jetliners can be flown by a single pilot in an emergency. Johnston told NBC her husband had a double-bypass heart surgery in 2006 but had been in otherwise good health and that the airline required him to have a physical every six months.
